p.s: As mentioned in the task ahead Starr is not afraid to speak anymore, because she starts to chant with the other protestors and also speaks to them about Khalil's life.
Starr does not think that she does not belong to this protest.
She has started to chant with the others because she still wants justice for the murder of Khalil and tells the crowd that she is the witness.
In lines 5-7 the point of view is the first person protagonist narrator.
It tells the story from Starr's point of view and has therefore a limited point of view and she only knowknows her own thoughts.
In this sight personal pronouns are used.
The effect on the reader is to portray the feelings of Starr on the night of Khalil's death.
A first person witness narrator is shown in lines 10-11 when Starr spots her attorney Ms. Ofrah.
The effect on the reader is to show the radical side of Starr's attorney and that Ms. Ofrah can lead a protest.
A first person wittnesswitness narrator is displayed in lines 24-25 as Ms. Ofrah turns to Starr.
The intended effect is to show that Ms. Ofrah does not recognize Starr imediatelyimmediately and needs a few seconds to recognize her.
A flashback is portrayed in (ll. 4-6).
The place of the protest is the place of Khalil's death and Starr remembers it immediately, even if it is already a long time ago when Khalil has been killed.
The effect on the reader is to display that all protestors know where Khalil died and that they see this place as holy ground.
It also displays that Starr is psychologically under pressure about Khalil's death and the protest.
In lines 18-22 a flashback and also a stream of conscionessconsciousness in form of the panoramic mode are shown.

It visualizes that Starr cannot protest at the beginning and due to the flashback and panoramic mode where Khalil's death is summarized in several sentences, the closer Starr comes to Khalil's death in her memories, her voice becomes louder and louder.
This shows, that Starr has to get over Khalil's death before she can actually start to speak up against racism.
The reader gets a short summary of the way how Khalil died.
In lines 52-53 is a flashback about the night of Khalil's death.
The reader should know that officer Brian Cruise has made a huge mistake when he has shot Khalil.

The most helpful technique is the flashback combined with the panoramic mode because the reader sees a development of Starr's state of mind during the protest and how her voice only gets louder the farther she gets over Khalil's death and that she is not afraid to speak up anymore.
